texts.es: Doña Emma es casada y madre de 3 hijos los tres mayores de edad, todos trabajan y tiene su propio hogar, su esposo trabaja como pintor ambulante el cual la ayuda con los gastos familiares,  trabaja como docente de la Escuela Rigoberto cabezas desde hace 22 años, está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 2do  crédito para pintar su vivienda y lograr que se mire mas bonita,  ademas de trabajar como maestra alquila tres habitaciones, de las cuales obtenien ingresos adicionales para el sustento familiar. Emma se ha caracterizado por ser una mujer  con alto espiritu de superación personal, responsable y trabajadora, es una docente que ama su trabajo ya que ayuda a muchos niños  a aprender a leer y escribir,  su sueño  es  tener estabilidad laboral, salud  y una vivienda con mejores condiciones para vivir con mayor comodidad.
texts.en:
Doña Emma is married and has three children, all of them adults. They all have jobs, and they have their own homes. Her husband works as an itinerant painter and helps her pay the household expenses. Emma has worked as a teacher in the Rigoberto Cabezas School for 22 years. She is asking for a second loan so that she can have her house painted and make it look better. As well as being a teacher, she rents out three rooms which provides the family with additional income. Emma is a high-spirited woman who knows how to get things done. She is a responsible and hard-working teacher who loves her work as she can help many children to learn to read and write. Her dream is to have a stable job, good health, and a better home so that she can live more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: María Lourdes

texts.es:
La señora María Lourdes C. tiene ya más de dos años dedicándose a la elaboración y venta de pasteles de queso.
Al negocio le está haciendo falta mas material para la elaboración, pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para la inversión, es por eso que está solicitando un crédito y así comprar el material que necesita para la elaboración de los pasteles que tiene por entregar.
Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia ya que tiene poco que se quedo viuda.
texts.en:
Señora María Lourdes C. has already worked for more than two years making and selling cheesecake. She needs more items for her business, but right now she doesn’t have any money to invest. For this reason she is asking for a loan to buy the ingredients she needs for the cheesecakes that she has to deliver to her customers. The business is the sole source of income for her family. They don't have very much as María is a widow.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making cheesecake

texts.es: Juana María Q. B. de 58 años los sábados y viernes recorre el mercado oriental y los talleres de calzado en busca de los modelos que desea comercializar. Luego lo distribuye entre sus clientes esto es un trabajo arduo pero que le llena de satisfacción el sentirse útil  y capaz.
texts.en:
Every Friday and Saturday 58-year old Juana María Q. B. goes to the eastern market and the workshops that make footwear looking for the styles of shoes she wants to buy. Then she delivers them to her customers. The work is hard but it fills her with satisfaction and makes her feel useful and capable.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: Francys Danelia vive en Nueva Guinea, es madre soltera de  una bebita de 4 añitos de edad, su mama la apoya con el cuido de la niña puesto que Francys tiene que viajar a una comarca a impartir el pan de la enseñanza a niños campesinos de esa comunidad, a pesar que no tiene la ayuda del papa de su hijo ella es una mujer muy responsable con su obligacion de madre, está solicitando su primer credito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda,  se caracteriza por ser honesta, trabajadora, de buenas costumbres, sociable y  muy responsable en su centro de trabajo y en sus compromisos adquiridos, su sueño es ir invirtiendo poco a poco en la casa y así gozar de mejores condiciones, que su tenga salud y    no le falte nada y tener estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Francys Danelia, lives in Nueva Guinea. She is a single mother of a four-year-old little girl. Her mother helps her care for her daughter because Francys travels to another district to teach the children of agricultural workers in the area. Despite not getting any support from her child's father, she is a very responsible parent. She is seeking her first loan to invest in home improvements. She is honest, hard-working, of good habits, sociable, and very responsible within her working environment and with her acquired obligations. Her dream is to invest in her home, bit by bit, so as to enjoy better living conditions, to have good health, to lack nothing, and to have work stability.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: Doña Furgencia vive a un kilometro de la colonia los Laureles donde cada día se va aumentando la población, es madre soltera de dos niños menores de edad quienes estudian la primaria en la escuela divino redentor, a pesar que no tiene la ayuda del padre de sus hijos ella ha tratado que no les falte nada, trabaja para el MINED como docente desde hace 8 años,está solicitando su 6to credito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda terminando de construirla, es una  profesora humilde, responsable, honesta, trabajadora y muy querida por sus compañeros de trabajo y su comunidad, actualmente esta estudiando su primer año de licenciatura en educacion en la universidad URACCAN. su sueño es ir mejorando la vivienda para asi tener mejor comodidad y vivir en un ambiente agradable, seguir estudiando para llegar a ser un excelente profesional, estabilidad laboral y salud.
texts.en:
Furgencia lives one kilometer from the Los Laureles neighborhood, where everyday you can see the population increasing. She is the single mother of two minor children. They are in the primary grades at the Divino Redentor School. In spite of not having the help of the father of her children, she has tried to make sure they do not need anything. She has worked as an elementary school teacher for MINED (Ministry of Education) for eight years. She is asking for her sixth loan to improve her house and finish building it. She is an unassuming, responsible, honest, and hard-working teacher. She is much loved by her work colleagues and her community. She is currently in her first year of studying for her education license at the URACCAN University. That way she will improve her house little by little. Her dreams are to keep on improving her house to be more comfortable and to live in a pleasant atmosphere, to keep studying to become an excellent professional, and to have stable work and health.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en:
Lagi P. is 68 and married with 8 children (ages 29 - 40).  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Lagi has 7 years of experience in this business.  Lagi needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 700 tala or US $292 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2006, Lagi joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Lagi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Lagi P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Emy

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of living of Mary Emy, 54. She supports two children in her family. Her 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field is just enough to provide their basic needs.

Mary Emy joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan with a low interest rate to finance her business. She’s requesting 8,000 Php to buy farm necessities and to sustain her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and to sustain her family

texts.es: Heydy Judith  trabaja como docente de educacion primaria en la Escuela Alfonso Cortes  desde hace 4 años, es madre de dos niños el mayor de 7 años de edad estudia su segundo grado de educacion primaria y niño menos de 2 añitos de edad, esposo trabaja como taxista y le apoya con los gastos del hogar.   Está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 2do crédito para la construcción de una habitación y asi brindarle mayor comodidad a su familia. Heydy recientemente se acaba de recibir de maestra de educacion primaria, su sueño es tener una vivienda con mejores condiciones,  se caracteriza por ser humilde en su labor de trabajo y en su comunidad, ademas desea seguir estudiando una licenciatura para ejercer su trabajo con mas experiencia, estabilidad laboral para así  ayudar a sus padres en los gastos familares.
texts.en:
Heydy Judith has been a teacher at the Alfonso Cortes elementary school for the last 4 years. She is the mother of two children: the eldest, 7, is in second grade and her youngest is under 2 years of age. Her husband is a taxi driver and he helps out with household expenses. She is requesting refinancing of her second loan in order to build a bedroom so that her family will be more comfortable. Heydy recently graduated as an elementary school teacher. Her dream is to have a home that is in better conditions. She is noted for being unassuming in her work and in her community. Besides, she wants to continue studying to get a bachelor degree so that she can continue in her profession with more experience and work stability so that she can help out her parents with family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: La profesora Mayra G. es casada,  trabaja como docente de educación primaria  desde hace 12 años, tiene 3 hijos, dos actualmente estudian su primaria y la niñita menor de 4 añitos en edad preescolar, su esposo trabaja en la finca que estos poseen en la colonia kurinwas, y se dedica al cultivo de granos basicos y cultivo de raices y tuberculos a cuidar su pequeño inventario ganadero que es el patrimonio de su familia,  está solicitando su 5to refinanciamiento para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda haciendo la division de los cuartos de la casa, y asi tener privacidad; doña Mayra con los creditos anteriores otorgados por AFODENIC a mejorado su vivienda y ha mejorado sus condiciones de vida, es una mujer que sueña con tener un porvenir mejor y que sus hijos tengan siempre lo basico y que estudien , trabajo y sobre todo estar bien con Dios.
texts.en:
Mayra G. has been an elementary school teacher for the past 12 years. She is married and has three children, two of whom are in elementary school and a daughter, who is under 4 years of age, who is a preschooler. Her husband works the farm that they have in the Kurinwas area; he grows basic grains and tubers while caring for a small herd of cattle, which is his family's assets. She asking for her fifth refinancing to invest in home improvements. She wants to subdivide the rooms so that they can have more privacy. With previous loans from AFODENIC, Mayra has improved her home and her living condiditons. She is a woman that dreams with having a better future and that her children always have their basic needs met, that they study, that she always has work and, above all, that she be in good standing with God.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: Miriam Eduvina  trabaja como directora de la Escuela Enmanuel Mongalo y Rubio  desde hace 16 años , vive en la zona  # 6 de Nueva Guinea junto a su familia compuesta por dos hijos y su esposo, los niños estudian en la misma escuela que ella y su esposo trabaja como mecanico, quien le apoya con con los gastos familiares. Miriam Eduvina tambien  imparte clases en la universidades que existen en el Municipio para obtener  ingresos adicionales que le permitan que su familia pueda vivir mejor, esta solicitando su 8vo refinanciamiento  con AFODENIC, para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda y terminar de construir la cocina de su casa,  pues actualmente la tiene en un rincosito de la sala; doña Miriam se ha caracterizado por ser una mujer luchadora, responsable que le gusta el progreso y ama su trabajo,  desde que obtuvieron su casa tanto ella como su esposo se han esforzado mucho para tener un hogar digno para su familia que cumpla con las condiciones que la familia necesita y su deseo es que sus hijas estudien para ser alguien en la vida, salud y trabajo.
texts.en:
Miriam Eduvina has been the principal at Enmanuel Mongalo y Rubio school for the past 16 years. She lives in Zone 6 of Nueva Guinea with her family, which is composed of her husband and two children. The children study at her school and her husband is a mechanic. He helps her with family expenses. Miriam Eduvina also teaches in the universities that are in the municipality in order to earn extra income that will allow her family to live better. She is asking for her 8th financing from AFODENIC to be used to make home improvements and to finish building her kitchen; currently it's in a corner of the living room. Miriam has always been a fighter, she is responsible, and likes to make progress in life and loves her job. Since they got their house, both she and her husband, have made every effort to have a proper home for the family, one that has all the requisite characteristics that the family needs. Their wish is that their daugthers study in order to become upstanding citizens, that they all have good health and work.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es:
El grupo Calle Real está integrado por cuatro mujeres trabajadoras, emprendedoras y luchadoras. Una de ellas es Xochilt R.  de 22 años quien para poder costear sus estudios universitarios en Contaduría Pública y Finanzas empezó hace tres años con un pequeño negocio  de venta de ropa usada y nueva  y cosméticos de las marcas zermat y avon. Ella el próximo año cursa cuarto año en la carrera y siente que todo lo que hace tiene un gran valor por el es fuerzo que significa.

Ángela G. de 24 años hace cuatro años comercializa respuestos de bicicletas y desea el próximo año seguir con sus estudios técnicos en caja y computación. De la misma manera Ada Luz Membreño  de 33 años quien  tiene una venta  y una gran meta  que es terminar quinto año de secundaria y como dice el dicho nunca es tarde para aprender.

 Mientras su compañera Juana A. quien vende perfumes, ropa y zapatos desea aumentar su negocio y seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
The Calle Real group is made up of four hard-working, enterprising and hard-fighting women. One of them is Xochilt R., 22 years old who, in order to pay for her university studies in public accounting and finance, began a small business three years ago selling new and used clothing and Zermat and Avon cosmetics. Next year she will be in the fourth year of her studies. She feels that everything she does is of great value for the strength that it signifies. Ángela G., 24 years old, sells bicycle parts and hopes next year to continue with her technical studies in commerce. In the same way, Ada Luz Membreño, 33 years old, has a market stall and a great goal, which is to finish her fifth year of high school. As the saying goes, it is never too late to learn. Meanwhile, their friend Juana A., who sells perfumes, clothes and shoes, hopes to build up her business and continue to work.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: Doña Rosibel  vive en la zona urbana de Nueva Guinea, es madre soltera y con grandes sacrificios crió a sus cuatros hijos quienes ya son mayores de edad y trabajan, y a pesar que no viven con ella  siempre esta al pendiente de ellos, actualmente ella trabaja como docente de primaria desde hace 15 años, está solicitando su 2do crédito para invertirlo en la construccion de una habitacion. Rosibel es una mujer  con alto espiritu de superación personal y laboral, muy responsable con sus compromisos, su sueño  es estudiar el proximo año para superarse profesionalmente, tener estabilidad, salud  y una vivienda  con mejores condiciones para su familia,  expresa sentirse agradecida con AFODENIC, ya que con los créditos anteriores logro construir poco a poco su vivienda y espera contar con el apoyo de KIVA para continuar mejorando su casa..
texts.en:
Rosibel lives in the town of Nueva Guinea. She is a single mother, and with great sacrifices she raised her four children who have now reached the age of majority and work. Although they no longer live with her she is always worried about them. Currently, she works as an elementary teacher, which she has done for 15 years. She is requesting her second loan to invest it in the construction of a house. Rosibel is a woman with a great spirit of excellence, both personally and in her work; she is very responsible with her commitments. Her dream is to study next year in order to excel professionally, to have stability, good health, and a home with better living conditions for her family. She says that she feels grateful to AFODENIC, as with her previous loans she managed to work bit by bit on the construction of her home, and she hopes to depend on the support of KIVA to continue improving her house.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es:
A la vivienda del la señora Rosa Herminia C. le está haciendo falta el vitropiso, pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para comprar el material.
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para poder realizar la mejora, ya que tiene nietos pequeños de edad y andan jugando en el piso y no quiere que se enfermen. 
Planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos que obtiene de su trabaja de limpieza de casa en la vecina ciudad de Nuevo Laredo.
texts.en:
The home of Mrs. Rosa Herminia C. is missing ceramic tiling for the floors, but at this time she does not have the money necessary to purchase the materials. It is for this this she is requesting a loan, in order to carry out the improvement to her home, as she has very young grandchildren who play around on the floor and she doesn't want them to get sick. She plans to pay back the loan with the income she gets from her housecleaning work in the neighbouring city of Nuevo Laredo.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

texts.es: Sonia Hernández, Jennifer A. y Juliana Catalina
texts.en: The Sacuanjoche, national flower of Nicargua, is the group name chosen by its members: Sonia Hernández, Jennifer A. & Juliana Catalina

texts.es: Sugey es soltera y no tiene hijos, actualmente vive con sus padres en la zona # 6 de Nueva Guinea donde la población cada dia crece mas,  y les apoya con los gastos familares, trabaja como docente de la Escuela Experimental Jan Amos Comenius desde hace 8 años, está solicitando su quinto crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (Repellar la casa),  por las tardes cuando regresa de dar clase se dedica a terminar los quehaceres del hogar y despues a planear la clase para luego impartirselas el dia siguientes a sus alumnos,  Sugey es una mujer  profesional responsable, honesta, trabajadora,  sueña con  seguir  estudiando, tener salud, tener una casa bonita con todas las condiciones y tener estabilidad laboral para así ayudar a su familia ya son de escasos recursos económicos.
texts.en:
Sugey is single and has no children. She lives with her parents in Zone 6 of Nueva Guinea, which is a fast-growing area. She helps them with household expenses working as a teacher at the Jan Amos Comenius Experimental School. She has worked there for the last 8 years. She is asking for her fifth loan to make home improvements (replastering the house). In the afternoon, when she comes home from teaching, she finishes her domestic chores and then plans her classes for the next day. Sugey is a professional, responsible, honest, hard-working woman. She dreams with continuing her education, with having good health, a pretty home with all the comforts, and to have stable work so that she can continue to help her family, who are of very limited economic resources.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Nia

texts.en:
Nia T. is 54 and married with 6 children (ages 17 - 38).  She owns a business venture, selling pork products in the local community.  Nia has 3 years of experience in this business.  Nia needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Nia joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Nia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Nia T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase pork products, flavoring, sugar and plastic bags

texts.es: William Oswaldo es soltero, se desempeña como docente de secundaria en la Escuela Cesar Augusto Salinas Pinell desde hace varios años, como aun no se ha casado vive con sus ancianos padres y un hermano a quienes les ayuda con los gastos del hogar,  actualmente este cliente esta cursando su ultimo semestre de la Carrera ciencias de la Educacion en la Universidad URACCAN y es el presidente estudiantil de la universidad,  el se ha caracterizado por ser un joven alegre, amistoso, responsable y de muchos deseos de superacion personal y profesional. Esta solicitando  su 4to refinanciamiento para invertirlo en la construccion de una habitacion y asi tener mayor privacidad, el se siente agradecido con AFODENIC ya que con los créditos anteriores ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y comprar sus electrodomésticos, el aspira para este proximo año estudiar un post grado para vivir actualizado con sus estudios, su sueño es tener trabajo para que a su familia no le falte nada y salud.
texts.en:
For several years, William Oswaldo has worked as a high school teacher at the Cesar Augusto Salinas Pinell School. He's not married, so he lives with his elderly parents and his brother, and helps them with household expenses. William is in his final semester of the Science Education program at URACCAN University. He's also the student body president. William is known as a happy, friendly, responsible, highly motivated student. This is his fourth loan, and he'll use it to create a room for himself in his parents' home, where he can have more privacy. William is grateful to AFODENIC because his previous loans have allowed him to afford home appliances and improve his family's living conditions. Next year he plans to begin graduate studies, and he hopes that by earning a good living, he'll be able to take care of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Sapi

texts.en:
Sapi T. is 54 and married with 5 children (ages 15 - 38).  She owns a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam).  Sapi has 3 years of experience in this business.  Sapi needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Sapi joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sapi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Sapi T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Maria tiene 56 años de edad, mujer trabajadora y esforzada en todos estos largos años ha logrado poder hacer su casa de concreto, trabaja como cocinera en un colegio privado y comercializa ropa en tiempos libres, durante veintiún año a laborado para el colegio, en la venta de ropa hace tres año lo hizo con el propósito de obtener  otros ingresos, ya que su mama se enfermo y tenia que comprarle el medicamento, pues para ella ha sido difícil salir adelante con sus dos hijos ya ahora mayor por ser madre soltera, y ahora que mi madre falleció ha sido muy triste. Con el crédito anterior logro hacer un muro para mejor seguridad, y con este préstamo comprara material de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, zinc para comenzar la obra, para terminar de construir un cuarto, falta parte del techo y las divisiones. Para su negocio es aumentar el inventario de su venta para poder sacar para su cuota, y sus necesidades diarias. Muy contenta ya que a través del financiamiento ha logrado poder hacer las mejora de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Maria, 56, is a hard-working woman who, after many long years of effort, has managed to build her concrete house. She works as a cook in a private school and in her spare time sells clothing. She has worked for the school for 21 years and in clothing sales for 3 years. She began the latter in order to earn extra income because her mother fell ill and she needed to buy medicines. It has been a difficult struggle for her. She was a single mother to her two children, now adults. Now that her mother has passed away, it is very sad for her. With her previous loan she built a wall for better security. She will use this one to buy building materials like: stone, sand, cement, iron, zinc metal sheeting, to start a project: she wants to finish building a bedroom, complete the roof, which is missing a section, and put up the interior dividing walls. For her business, she wants to increase stock so that her earnings will also increase thereby meeting her required sales quota to meet daily expenses. She is very happy that the financing has allowed her to make improvements on her home.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stone, sand, cement, iron, and zinc metal sheeting to finish enclosing her house.

texts.es: Jancy es casada, tiene un  niña de 8 años de edad estudia su tercer grado de educacion primaria, su esposo trabaja actualmente esta trabajando en Costa Rica con el objetivo de mejorar sus condicones de vidayle envia remesas para los gastos familiares, actualmente trabaja como docente  en la Escuela Ruben Dario  de Nueva Guinea desde hace 9 años, está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 6to crédito para  construir  una habitación, Jancy  a pesar que es una docente asalariada ha demostrado ser una mujer muy responsables, honesta y muy trabajadora, tiene gran espiritu de superación profesional y laboral, expresa que se siente agradecida con la institución de AFODENIC  ya que con los anteriores logro tener su propia casa, su sueño para el futuro es estudiar una post grado este proximo año, salud para sus familia y tener estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Jancy is married and the mother of an 8-year-old daughter, who is a third-grader. Her husband is working in Costa Rica hoping to improve their living conditions. He sends money home for family expenses. She has worked as a teacher at the Ruben Dario school in Nueva Guinea for the last 9 years. She is asking for her 6th loan to build a bedroom. Jansy, although being a salaried teacher, has shown herself to be a very responsible, honest, and hard-working woman. She has a strong will to better herself both professionally and work-wise. She is grateful to AFODENIC since her previous loans allowed her to get her own house. Her dreams for the future is to study a post-graduate course next year, that her family enjoys good health, and that she have job security.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie T. is 19 and single with 1 child.  She owns a business venture, selling fried foods in the local community.  Marie has 3 years of experience in this business.  Marie needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Marie joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Marie's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Marie T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: El Futuro Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Futuro se conformo cuando María Salvadora M. y Mirvania del Carmen M. necesitaban financiamiento para mejorar sus negocios pero muchas puertas se le cerraron es entonces que llegaron Adim y decidieron formar un grupo.  Luego se integraron  a ellas Cecilia Castro  y Martha Elena G. desde entonces ya llevan 14 ciclos en los cuales sus negocios han ido creciendo 

María Salvadora M. de 44 años hace tortilla, nacatamales y sopa de mondongo, Cecilia Castro R. tiene un negocio de  destace de cerdo y venta de ropa, Martha Elena Gonzales de 50 años vende cosméticos  y Milvannia tiene una venta.

Ellas esperan que este nuevo año les vaya bien con su negocio, tener salud y fuerzas para seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The El Futuro group was formed when María Salvadora M. and Mervannia del Carmen M. needed a loan to improve their businesses. Unfortunately, many lenders closed the door on them, so they contacted Adim and decided to form a group. Cecilia Castro and Martha Elena G. soon joined them, and their businesses have been growing ever since. María is 44 years old. She makes tortillas, nacatamales and mondongo (tripe) soup. Cecilia butchers pigs and sells clothing. Martha is 50 years old, and she sells cosmetics. Mervannia has a shop. The group hopes that the New Year will bring success in business, good health and the strength to be determined.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for tortillas, nactamales and soup

loans.name: Meleane

texts.en:
Meleane S. is 39 and married with 5 children (ages 4 - 16).  She owns a business venture, cultivating fruit trees & harvesting its fruit for sale.  Meleane has 4 years of experience in this business.  Meleane needs a loan of WST $2750 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

Meleane joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Meleane's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Meleane S. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.4 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.4 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.4 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

loans.name: Leonel Guadalupe

texts.es:
El señor Leonel Guadalupe M. tiene ya más de seis años dedicándose al oficio de herrería.
  Al negocio le está haciendo falta materia prima y herramienta mas moderna, pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para la inversión que desea realizar a su negocio. 
Don Leonel Guadalupe tiene bajo su responsabilidad un hijo que actualmente está estudian y desea lo mejor.
Con una parte de las ganancias del negocio planea pagar el crédito.
texts.en:
Leonel Guadalupe M. has been a blacksmith for over 6 years. His business is lacking raw materials and more modern equipment. However, he does not have funds now to invest in his business the way he'd like to. He has a son under his care who is a student and he wants the best for him. He plans to repay the loan with part of his business profits.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and work tools.

texts.en: 24-year-old Shyryl farms for a living. She is married and has a four-year-old child. She wants to save up for her child’s future so she works hard to do that. She cultivates her land for rice crops. She shares that her harvest went well and she hopes to double it up this time. She is now preparing the land for planting and is in need of farm supplies. She requested a loan of 12,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies needed at her farm. This loan will help Shyryl have an abundant harvest.

Carine has been married to her husband Ranel since 2004. She is 25 years old and has a 5-year-old child. She is involved in rice farming and also raises pigs to bring in additional income for her family. She wants to grow her business so she works hard to achieve that. She also sought the help of MFIs and was able to join CEVI. She applied for a loan of 12,000 PHP. She will use this loan for farm supplies, like seeds and fertilizers. She will also set aside some for feed. Hopefully, this loan will help Carine grow her business.

loans.name: Uila

texts.en:
Uila is 38 and married with 2 children (ages 2 and 9).  She owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has many years of experience in this business.    Uila needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Uila joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Uila's 3rd loan with SPBD. 

Falefia, a loan manager at SPBD, asked Uila a couple of questions about her business.  Here are her answers:

Overall Social Metric Score of Uila V. provided by SPBD:*               1.5 out of 3

texts.en: Ann Joy is a 26-year-old married woman from Agusan del Sur. She has a 6-year-old child whom she loves taking care of. She has dreams for her family, which she is eager to achieve. She is involved in rice farming and currently owns a hectare of rice field. She says her rice crops need some supplies in order to grow healthy. She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI, which she will use to purchase the necessary supplies for her farm.

Emma, 39 years old, is a married woman. She has a 5-year-old child. She wants to give a bright future to her child. She also wants to improve her family’s living conditions. She is into rice farming. According to her, her land is now being prepared for the next planting. She wants to achieve an abundant harvest.

Emma joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP. She will use this loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies needed at her farm.

texts.en:
Mr. Renato E. is a farmer. He started farming in 1999 and cultivates his land for rice crops. He also owns a rice mill (a machine used to remove the chaff and outer husks from rice grains). He has a 14-year-old child whom he wishes to finish school someday.

Renato joined CEVI and likes its low interest rate. He is in need of additional capital for his business so he applied for Php 15,000. He will use this loan to finance his farm, buying seeds, fertilizers and other farming necessities.

38-year-old Wenefredo is a married man from Agusan Del Sur. He has two children and the oldest is 17 years old. He is involved in rice farming. Like other farmers, he also experienced failures in farming. He said that there were times when he didn’t have income at all. He is currently preparing his land for planting. He wants to make sure his crops will grow healthy so he will have a good harvest. He requested a loan of Php15, 000 from CEVI. With this loan, Wenefredo will be able to buy farm inputs, like seeds and fertilizers for his land.

Mr. Romy D. is a farmer. He is 33 years old, married and has three children. The oldest of his children is only 11 years old. He works hard for his family, especially his children’s education. He wants all of them to someday finish school and find a decent job for themselves. As a farmer, hard work is required at the farm. He makes sure to keep himself healthy and strong so he can do his duties and earn an income for his family. He thanks God for another opportunity that he could plant rice on his farm again. He is now preparing for planting. He will need farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers and others. He applied for a loan of Php15, 000 from CEVI. He will use this loan to finance his farm.

Jenalyn is a 34-year-old married woman. She has two children and the oldest is only 15 years old. She has engaged in rice farming in 1998. She currently owns a hectare of rice field and also maintains an 8-hectare rice field, which adds to her income. She hopes that someday she could grow her own farm so she does not have to work at other people’s land. She shared that her farm is now being prepared for planting. She applied for a loan of Php15, 000 from CEVI to assist her financially. She will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs she needs. Hopefully, this loan will help Jenalyn expand her own farm.

Presie, 30 years old, ventured into rice farming in 2000. She is a married woman and has two children with her husband, Loreto. She is happy to say that her business is doing well and she is now preparing her land for planting. She wants to maintain her farm's good condition so it is productive and gives her a better income. Presie needs additional capital for her farm so she applied to CEVI for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). With this loan, Presie will be able to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers.

loans.name: Las Tigresas Group

texts.en:
The members of our group, Las Tigresas (which means “The Tigers” in Spanish), are part of the Asociación Arariwa. This communal bank consist of 16 members from the San Jeronimo district of the city of Cusco.  The majority of our group members work in a large market in Cusco, although some are nurses in a local hospital.

Ruth is the president of our group.  She lives with her spouse and three children in Cusco.  Ruth has been selling breakfast at a stand in the market for nine years.  Her husband works afternoons and nights as a taxi driver and helps Ruth run her stand in the morning. Ruth needs a loan to improve her stand and to help get her through the Christmas season.  Her New Year's resolution is to save enough money next year to build a house.    

Most of the members of Las Tigresas sell food. Some, like Ruth, sell meals in the market, while others sell cheeses, fruit juice, or sell food wholesale.  The group members will use their loans to improve their businesses and for personal uses, such as paying for improvements to their homes, or paying for their children’s education. 

All of the group members appreciate and thank you for the loan. They promise to pay the monthly payments on time. 

(All but two of the group members appear in the video, which shows a group member toasting the coming New Year during the first meeting of the communal bank.)

loans.use: Operating capital for their businesses and for personal use

texts.en: At 44, Ruben is still single. Despite that, he is still happy to be living. He is a farmer and spends most of his time working on the farm. He wants to expand his farm. He has hired some laborers to help him prepare the land for planting. He says that he needs farm inputs but is not able to purchase everything he needs. He applied to CEVI for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). He will use this loan to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and other things.

Merlinda, age 59, is now a widow. She has been left with seven children to take care of (the oldest, who is now 42, does not live with them anymore). She is involved in rice farming and does her best to keep up with her family’s growing needs. She says that she harvested 60 sacks of rice last time. She hopes to harvest more in the future, so she can increase her earnings. 
Merlinda applied to CEVI for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which she will use to finance her farm. With this loan, Merlinda will be able to purchase needed seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna, 39 years old, is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is only 14 years old and goes to school. She wants all of her children to have a proper education.

Myrna is into rice farming, which is the only source of income her family has. She hopes to grow her farm so she can earn more. 

Myrna joined CEVI a year ago and feels blessed to have gained access to its financial services. She is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farming necessities. This loan will help immensely to enable Myrna’s farm to grow.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farming necessities

texts.en: Leilyn farms for a living. She is 28 years old and has been married for two years. She has a 2-year-old child. To finance her farm, she used to borrow from loan sharks but she was not able to save money and sometimes her income was hardly enough to feed her family. Upon learning about CEVI from fellow farmers, she settled her obligations and joined the MFI. She likes CEVI's program and thinks that the low interest rate is very helpful to farmers like her. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). She will use this loan to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

texts.es:
El señor Juan M. está agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual le pudo ayudar a si suegra, que ya esta mucho mejor.  
Nuevamente está solicitando un préstamo ya que desea mejorar su vivienda y le está haciendo falta el vitropiso, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para llevar a cabo la mejora. 
Planea pagar el crédito con su ingreso que obtiene como guardia de seguridad, ya que los gastos familiares se encargara su esposa la señora Manuela Reyna quien también trabaja de guardia de seguridad. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la Doña Manuel Reyna esposa del señor Juan, ya que el se encontraba en su trabaja el día de la visita a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan M. is grateful for your support with his previous loan with which he was able to help his mother-in-law, who is now much better. Today he is seeking a loan as he wishes to improve his home and he is in need of ceramic flooring, but at this moment he doesn’t have the money needed to finish with this improvement. He plans to pay back the loan with the income he receives as a security guard, as his family expenses are paid for by his wife, Mrs. Manuela Reyna, who also works as a security guard. The person appearing in the photo is Mrs. Manuela Reyna, wife of Juan, who was working the day we visited his home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Rene, 34, lives in Banga, South Cotabato, and has a rice farming business. He devotes his time to working in his 1 hectare rice field. He heard that Community Economic Ventures, Inc. offers financial support to entrepreneurs like him and he joined in June, 2008. His business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). This money will help sustain his business with a low interest charge.

Horn S., 42, is married and lives with her three school-aged children and husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She used to sell groceries in her village but business was not good. As a result, she started a new business selling fruit in the city. She has been involved in this business since 2008 and is able to earn US $5 per day. Her husband (in the photo) drives a motorbike in the city earning US $4 per day. Her husband helps with her business every morning, preparing to sell to their regular customers, then he travels around the city offering his transportation services.

S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. As a result, she is requesting a loan of US $500 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. This is her first loan from CREDIT. She wants to use the loan to purchase a new motorbike for her husband because the old motorbike often goes broken.

Fagaitaua F. is 43 and married with 6 children.  She owns a business venture, selling puletasi (Samoan formal wear).  Fagaitaua has 2 years of experience in this business.  Fagaitaua needs a loan of WST $1250 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

Fagaitaua joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Fagaitaua's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep S., 50, is married and lives with her three children and husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. S. is pictured with her husband in the photo.

S. has been involved in a business selling vegetables and fish since 1985 and is able to earn a gross income of US$18 per day. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver everywhere in the province, earning an income of US$8 per day. The family is also assisted by one of her children who is a worker at a local garment factory, earning an income of US$4 per day.

S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US$1,200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase a new motorbike for one of her children to use to commute to work. This is her second loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for one of her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Menime

texts.en:
Menime P. is 42 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Menime has 5 years of experience in this business.  Menime needs a loan of WST $2450 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Menime joined SPBD, and this is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Menime's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Menime P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim N. lives in Daeum Rumdael village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables.  She faces an obstacle in that she does not have enough money to buy farming supplies. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers, and pesticides, as well as pay for plowing the field. Her husband, Mr. Phun Min, is a construction worker. Mrs. Kim N. is 39 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides, and to pay for plowing

loans.name: Vaialalua

texts.en:
Vaialalua U. is 25 and single with no children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Vaialalua  has 3 years of experience in this business.  Vaialalua  needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

Vaialalua  joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Vaialalua 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Vaialalua  U. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives

loans.name: Doeun

texts.en:
Mr. Doeun H. lives in Krang Roung village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. He faces some problems because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed, and his field is far from any irrigation system. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and a water machine. 

His wife, Mrs. Tun Naem, is a pig breeder. Mr. Doeun H. is 58 years old and the father of six children; one is a security guard, two are farmers, and the others are enrolled in the local school. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and irrigation equipment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea E., 25, is married and lives with her two childrE. and husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has beE. in the business of selling vegetables since 2004 and is able to earn a gross income of $21 United States dollars (USD) per day. 

Her husband operates a business of selling greE. and ripe coconuts everywhere in the province, earning a gross income of $24 USD per day. This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure a good standard of living for the childrE. and the family. 

Chea and her husband are seeking to improve their businesses. As a result, Chea is requesting a loan of $800 USD from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to purchase a trailer to attach to the motorbike to transport coconuts for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a trailer to attach to the motorbike in order to transport coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Kim San

texts.en:
Mr. Kim San D. (pictured next to his wife) is a villager in Prey Mien village in the province of Takeo. He is 34 years old and the father of six children, five of whom attend the local school. His youngest child is too young to work or study.

Kim San works as a battery charger. His wife, Mrs. Neang Sophal, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. With this plantation, Mr. Kim San D. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding and to help him plow the field.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding and to help him plow his rice field.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aveina

texts.en:
Aveina T. is 40 and married with 1 child (8 years-old).  She owns a business venture, catching & selling ocean-caught fish .  Aveina has 3 years of experience in this business.  Aveina needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Aveina joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Aveina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Overall Social Metric Score provided by SPBD:*                1.9 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Vai

texts.en:
Mr. Vai S. (pictured with his wife) is a villager in Krang Roung village in Takeo province. Vai is 36 years old and the father of four children, three of whom are attending the local school. The youngest child is just 6 months old. 

Vai is an ice cream seller. He is requesting a loan to add to his savings so that he can buy a motorbike to transport the ice cream he sells. His wife, Mrs. Say Ney, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to make a living.

loans.use: To add to his savings to buy a motorbike to transport the ice cream he sells.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mr. San S. and his wife live in Pursat province, Cambodia with their one young child who is enrolled in school and dependent on them. This couple has been earning their living by growing a variety crops on their own farmland. 

In addition, San always leaves home to go to the markets where he supplies a taxi service. At the market, he is hired by market sellers to deliver their merchandise and to drive their valued retail customers around the community. He earns approximately $6 each day for this work. 

Recently, San's taxi has often broken during the times in which he operates his service, and that affects his income. Thus, San would like to request a loan to replace his old existing taxi.

loans.use: To replace his old existing taxi.

loans.name: Luafalealii

texts.en:
Luafalealii T. is 35 and married with 1 child (4 years-old).  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Luafalealii has 3 years of experience in this business.  Luafalealii needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Luafalealii joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Luafalealii's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Luafalealii's Social Metrics provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.9 out of 3

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Sitoe

texts.en:
Sitoe is 50 and married with 5 children (ages 8-20).  She owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has 3 years of experience in this business.    Sitoe needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Sitoe joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Sitoe's 1st loan with SPBD. 

Overall Social Metric Score for Sitoe A. provided by SPBD:*               1.9 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3 

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.
